unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Simulation of Multiple Choice Test
question_text:
Last week, Abby completely forgot to study for her multiple choice test.
She decides to randomly guess on each question. Suppose the test has four answer possibilities for each question (A, B, C, and D).
How could one use simulation to determine the number of questions she could answer correctly until she gets one wrong?

choices.text: Assign digit 1 to answers correctly; assign digit 2 to answers incorrectly.
Assign digits 0-4 to answers correctly; assign digits 5-9 to answers incorrectly.
Assign digits 0-1 to answers correctly; assign digits 2-9 to answers incorrectly.
Assign digits 0-1 to answers correctly; assign digits 2-7 to answers incorrectly.
Assign digits 2-4 to answers correctly; assign digit 1 to answers incorrectly.

solution:
If Abby is totally guessing on a four-choice multiple choice test, she has a $25\%$ chance of success.

Therefore, one must assign digits in such a manner that $25\%$ of digits represent success, and $75\%$ of the digits represent failure. Only Choice 'D' does this.
